New Deal Nation,
As I read the comments concerning the postponement of graduation please understand that as a district this was a very difficult decision. We had over 260 chairs set up on the football field ready to go for the audience. We had large poster size pictures attached to the fence of every graduate. We had everything set up to live stream the graduation ceremony. The diplomas are stacked and ready to be distributed to the graduates. The flowers for the graduates had been purchased. We have put more time and effort into this years graduation because we want to honor the class of 2020 in the most appropriate way possible. I am available to visit with any parent that would like to visit. Please call me at (806) 746-5833. Also please understand that due to FERPA laws we are not able to disclose all information. The decision was made in the best interest of the New Deal HS graduates. I look forward to honoring the Class of 2020 on June 11, 2020.

Matt Reed
Superintendent

I regret to inform you that due to a circumstances outside the District’s control involving public safety, New Deal ISD, in an abundance of caution, has made the difficult decision to postpone the New Deal High School 2020 graduation ceremony currently scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on June 4, 2020. The District will evaluate future dates for conducting the graduation ceremony when it may comply with TEA and CDC guidelines. The health and safety of New Deal ISD student, parents, and guests are of paramount importance to the District, and we apologize for any inconvenience this postponement may have caused you and your families. We look forward to honoring our graduating seniors at a future date when we can do so safely for all participants and attendees. New Deal ISD will release more information as it becomes available about when the rescheduled graduation ceremony will take place.

Matt Reed
Superintendent

Eligible P-EBT families will receive application instructions from schools in late May. The P-EBT application will open the first week of June.

A STOPPED SCHOOL BUS: WHAT DO I DO?

Texas State law requires that drivers stop when a school bus is operating a visual signal-either red flashing lights or extended stop arm (TRC 545.066). However, many Texas drivers are uncertain as to when they need to stop for a school bus.

Here are a few guidelines to reduce driver confusion, thus providing a safer environment for our children. #BackToSchoolSafety
